thread.title: Transport Secretary Chris Grayling admits rail franchising system 'no longer works'

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Transport Secretary Chris Grayling admits rail franchising system 'no longer works'
text:
Transport Secretary Chris Grayling admits rail franchising system 'no longer works' In blunt admission of failure, the transport secretary admitted 'trains are packed, the network is creaking' Share Transport Secretary Chris Grayling (Image: Getty Images Europe) Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
The existing rail franchising system “no longer works”, Transport Secretary Chris Grayling has admitted.
He said the chaos on Northern Rail services over the summer showed why rail services need “wholesale change.”
And he admitted the rail network was struggling to cope with the huge increase in passenger numbers that took place over the past 20 years.
Mr Grayling said: “Trains are packed. The network is creaking. Passengers experience too many things going wrong.”
He told the Conservative conference that he apologised for the problems on the rail network this year, and added: “For us as Conservatives it was particularly frustrating.”
The Transport Secretary highlighted his proposals to change the way rail franchises operate, in order to join up management of the trains and of rail track and associated infrastructure such as signals.
Mr Grayling said: “The chaos cannot and will not be allowed to happen again.
“But it is clear that the system has greater challenges than a failed timetable introduction.”
He said the Government was investing more in rail services in the North than previous Labour governments, and the Northern Rail franchise was replacing and refurbishing every single train. Read More Business Secretary Greg Clark warns Tories must listen to carmakers such as Nissan over Brexit
But he claimed: “I do not believe the industry is making the most of our investment.
“It’s clear that the way our railways are run no longer works when the system is under pressure.
“Last year we started to evolve towards a more joined up railway. One team running track and train.”
A Government White Paper next year will detail plans for “a rail revolution”, he said.
Mr Grayling also used the speech to announce a new system making it easier to claim compensation for delayed or cancelled rail journeys.
It will mean passengers need only make ‘one-click’ to submit their claim once registered rather than entering their details every time. New operators will be expected to make greater use of technology to inform passengers when they are entitled to claim compensation, such as through mobile phone apps. The Transport Secretary said the Government had launched “the biggest roads upgrade programme for decades”, and highlighted the upgrade of the A1 between Leeming and Barton, which opened earlier this year.
He said: “We’ve just opened the last leg of motorway grade road from London to Newcastle. Heaven knows why that didn’t happen years ago. And it certainly didn’t happen when Labour was in power.” Like us on Facebook
